channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistan Suffers Record Flooding, Turning Villages Into Islands
item.description: The flooding has displaced more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amira, 15, at center, is helped by her husband to walk through water on the edge of Johi town. She had given birth just a few days before.

item.title: How Is Climate Change Affecting Floods?
item.description: Like other extreme weather disasters, flooding involves a number of competing factors that may affect its frequency and intensity.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao

item.title: In New York City, Pandemic Job Losses Linger
item.description: Even as the country as a whole has recovered all of the jobs it lost during the pandemic, the city is still missing 176,000 — the slowest recovery of any major metropolitan area.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Matthew Haag
item.category: New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The number of international tourists, business travelers and commuters in New York has yet to return to its prepandemic level, hurting the workers who serve them.

item.title: Social Security’s Cost-of-Living Increase Will Be Largest in Four Decades, an Estimate Says
item.description: Retirees will learn the amount of the increase for 2023 in October, and the current estimate is that it will be 8.7%.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.media:credit: Valerie Macon/AFP, via Getty Images
item.media:description: More than 70 million people — including retirees, those receiving disability and very low-income Americans — will be affected by the benefit increase.

item.title: Ostracized by the West, Russia Finds a Partner in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The two oil-producing countries have extended their partnership even as the United States and Europe have sought to punish and isolate Russia for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yuri Kadobnov
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in 2019. The leaders have worked together to prop up global oil prices.

item.title: Russian missiles hit a dam in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian cruise missile attack on a dam caused flooding in the industrial city of Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Top E.U. Official Becomes an Unexpected Wartime Leader
item.description: In her annual address, Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, pushed for the bloc to remain firm in the face of Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Christophe Petit Tesson/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, addressing the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Wednesday.

item.title: Who Will Pay for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral
item.description: The state will cover the huge price tag at a time when many in Britain are struggling to pay their bills and are bracing for a difficult winter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: The cost of Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral has not yet been made public.

item.title: The Mystery Behind the Crime Wave at 312 Riverside Drive
item.description: In thousands of 911 calls, one man has reported murders, fights, bombs and hostage situations at a Manhattan address that does not exist. Why?
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Sarah Blesener for The New York Times

item.title: California Files Antitrust Lawsuit Against Amazon
item.description: Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, said the retailer punishes companies that offer lower prices on other websites.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and David McCabe
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California officials say Amazon is punishing retailers who offer lower prices on alternative sites on the internet.

item.title: E.U. Scores Major Legal Victory Against Google
item.description: A court rejected Google’s appeal of a record-setting antitrust fine related to Android and online search.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Stephanie Lecocq/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager has led the European Commission’s efforts to regulate tech giants like Amazon, Apple, Google and Meta.

item.title: How a Spreader of Voter Fraud Conspiracy Theories Became a Star
item.description: For more than a decade, Catherine Engelbrecht, a Texas mom turned election-fraud crusader, has sown doubts about ballots and voting. Her patience has paid off.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

item.title: They Translated ‘Hamilton’ Into German. Was It Easy? Nein.
item.description: For the musical’s Hamburg premiere, a team wrestled with language and cultural differences to bring the story alive for a new audience.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Florian Thoss for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gino Emnes (Aaron Burr) and Benet Monteiro (Alexander Hamilton) are in the German production of “Hamilton.”

item.title: Six Lyrics That Show Why ‘Hamilton’ Is Tough to Translate
item.description: A direct transfer of words was never going to work for such a complex show. So the team involved got creative.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Clay Hickson

item.title: A Journey Through Black Nova Scotia
item.description: The 400-year history of African culture in this maritime Canadian province is expansive, but it’s a story that’s been tucked into the shadows of Canadian history. Now, grass-root initiatives are changing that.
item.dc:creator: Shayla Martin
item.media:credit: Carolina Andrade for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burial ground for Black Loyalists in Birchtown, Nova Scotia. Thousands of free and enslaved Africans known as Black Loyalists fought during the American Revolution on the side of the British. But once British defeat seemed inevitable, more than 3,000 Loyalists departed New York for Nova Scotia.

item.title: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
item.description: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lines from President Biden’s teleprompter during a speech in Maryland in August.

item.title: China Is Running Covert Operations That Could Seriously Overwhelm Us
item.description: The West isn’t nearly prepared enough for the scale and complexity of China’s all-of-nation covert offensive.
item.dc:creator: Nigel Inkster
item.media:credit: Anson Chan

item.title: Why Aren’t You Voting in Your Financial Self-Interest?
item.description: The conflict between elites and populists may not be what it seems.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
item.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Bettmann Archive/Getty Images

item.title: Ukraine’s Achievement Is Biden’s, Too
item.description: As Russian troops flee their positions, now is the time to press the military advantage.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier waves to passing buses near the recaptured village of Verbivka, Ukraine.

item.title: What It Took for Stella Levi to Talk About the Holocaust
item.description: How a chance meeting with one of the last Jews of Rhodes changed me.
item.dc:creator: Michael Frank

item.title: Putin Will Make People Choose Between Heating and Eating This Winter
item.description: To defeat petro-Putinism in Europe, U.S. energy policy has to be the arsenal of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Etienne De Malglaive/Getty Images

item.title: Bill Gates: ‘We’re in a Worse Place Than I Expected’
item.description: The philanthropist on how the pandemic and the effects of the war in Ukraine are setting back progress.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images

item.title: Poverty, Plunging
item.description: Child poverty in the U.S. has fallen by more than half since the early 1990s.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: The College Pricing Game
item.description: In the wake of student debt relief, an exploration of how higher education costs became such a complex issue.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Jessica Cheung, Eric Krupke, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yale’s Sterling Memorial Library. While President Biden has tackled the issue of student debt, he has not yet taken on the soaring cost of college.

item.title: Join Al Gore and John Kerry for a Times Climate Event
item.description: How does climate change exacerbate other global challenges? Join us remotely or in person for our climate event series, with an upcoming gathering in New York in September.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Did Hurricanes Sandy or Ida Damage Your Housing? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: We want to hear the stories of people in the New York City metro area who were affected by both storms.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: In Dramatic Shift, Right-Wing Bloc Wins Slim Majority in Sweden
item.description: Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson said on Wednesday that she would resign. Despite the success of the far-right Sweden Democrats, they will influence but are not expected to be formally part of the governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The new government is expected to be led by Ulf Kristersson, head of the Moderates, who would become prime minister in a minority administration made up of right-leaning parties.

item.title: A Uyghur Author and Translator Were Detained. Now, Their Novel Speaks For Them.
item.description: Writing and translating “The Backstreets,” a book about the oppressive environment faced by Uyghurs in China, was a danger to those involved.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May

item.title: How a Garbage-Bin War Schools Humans and Birds
item.description: Sulfur-crested cockatoos are trash-can bandits in the suburbs of Sydney, Australia. Humans use tools to protect their bins, and the birds then go the extra mile to break in.
item.dc:creator: Bethany Brookshire
item.media:credit: Ken Griffiths/Alamy
item.media:description: Sulfur-crested cockatoos enjoying a feast in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Rommy Hunt Revson, Creator of the Scrunchie, Dies at 78
item.description: A former nightclub singer, she developed the simple ornamental hair tie that quickly became a ubiquitous accessory.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: via Rommy Revson Estate
item.media:description: Rommy Hunt Revson in an undated photo. In 1986, she received a patent for a hairband made of fabric and elastic that came to be known as the Scrunchie, a hugely popular accessory in the 1980s and ’90s.

item.title: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
item.description: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Processed Meat and Health Risks: What to Know
item.description: Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Should You Put on Sunscreen or Foundation First?
item.description: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
item.dc:creator: Caira Blackwell
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
item.description: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Take on an Empty Stomach.’ How Do You Know When Your Stomach Is Empty?
item.description: Two hours after eating is a crude rule of thumb. A more accurate answer depends on the drugs you are taking and your medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Stuart Bradford

item.title: A New Look at a Diane Arbus Exhibition, 50 Years Later
item.description: David Zwirner Gallery in New York is restaging the photographer’s 1972 retrospective.
item.dc:creator: M.H. Miller
